detaileddescription.para: Constructs a default Vector3 setting it to a zero vector i.e. x=y=z=0.

memberdef.argsstring: (const float x, const float y, const float z)
memberdef.name: Vector3

detaileddescription.para: Constructs a Vector3 from the x, y and z floats passed in.
Constructs a Vector3 from the vector2 additionally setting the z component of this vector to 0.
Constructs a Vector3 from the Vector2 addionally setting the z component to z.
Constructs a Vector3 from the Vector4 dropping the w component of the Vector4.
Constructs a Vector3 from a 2d Point setting z=0.
todo in game loop Vector3 is constantly allocating and detroying each frame .... ?
Returns a Vector3 that is the cross product of this vector and otherVector i.e. this x otherVector. Note: The cross product is anticommutitive so a x b is not always equal to b x a.
Returns the dot product (a scalar value) of this vector and otherVector.
Returns the distance between two points represented by this vector and otherVector. The distance is defined as the length of the line segment between two points represented here with the vectors.
Tests whether this Vector3 is x=y=z=0. If so, true is returned and false if not.
Returns the calculation of this vector's length (also known as the magnitude).

Returns a normalised vector (has length of 1) that is perpendicular to this vector and vector b when the two vectors are placed tail to tail. i.e. a normalised version of the cross product of a and b. Note: if the vector does not need to be normalised then the cross product is sufficient enough and is slightly quicker.

This method normalises this vector. If this vector is a zero vector (i.e. where each component is 0) then it cannot be normalised and so nothing happens. A normlised vector (also called a unit vector) is one which still points in the same direction but has been scaled to have a length or magnitude of 1.

Returns a Vector3 that is a normalised version of this vector. This vector remains unchanged. If this vector is a zero vector (i.e. where each component is 0) then it cannot be normalised and a zero vector is returned instead. A normlised vector (also called a unit vector) is one which still points in the same direction but has been scaled to have a length or magnitude of 1.
Resets this Vector3 back to x=y=z=0.
Sets the x component of this vector.
Sets the y component of this vector.
Sets the z component of this vector.
Returns the x component of this vector.
Returns the y component of this vector.
Returns the z component of this vector.
Returns a Point object containing the x and y components of this vector while the z component is dropped. Note: Point uses integer precision so non-integer x and y coordinates will be rounded.
Returns a Vector2 version of this vector dropping the z component.
Returns a Vector2 version of this vector dropping the z component.
Adds the corresponding components of this vector and vector v together.
Subtracts the components of vector v from the corresponding components of this vector.
Multiplies each component of this vector by factor and returns a reference to this vector.
Multiplies the components of this vector by the corresponding components of vector v.
If divisor is not 0 then each component of this vector is divided by divisor, otherwise nothing happens. Either way a reference to this vector is returned.
Assignment operator assigns the component values of v to this vector.
Returns a basic vector that represents the forward axis (0,0,1).
Returns a basic vector that represents the up axis (0,1,0).
Returns a basix vector that represents the right axis (1,0,0).

Returns a Vector3 that is the cross product of a and b i.e. a x b. The cross product of two vectors yields a vector that is perpendicular to the two vectors when the two vectors are placed tail to tail. Note: The cross product is anticommutitive so a x b is not always equal to b x a.

Returns the dot product of vectors a and b (the length of the projection of b onto a, multiplied by the length of a). The dot product of the two vectors is the sum of the products of corresponding components which results in a scalar. The dot product of two vectors a and b is also equal to the cosine of angle theta between the two vectors placed tail to tail multiplied by the lengths of the vectors i.e. a.b = ||a||||b||cos(theta)
Returns the distance between two points. The distance is defined as the length of the line segment between two points represented here with the vectors.

Returns a normalised vector (has length of 1) that is perpendicular to the vectors a and b when they are placed tail to tail. i.e. a normalised version of the cross product of a and b. Note: if the vector does not need to be normalised then the cross product is sufficient enough and is slightly quicker.
Returns a normalised vector that is perpendicular to the plane defined by the vectors b-a and c-a. It will have unit length i.e. 1.
Returns a Vector3 that is the result of adding the components of vector a and vector b.
Returns a Vector3 that is the result of subtracting the components of vector b from vector a. Note: vector subtraction is not commutitive so a-b does not always equal b-a
Returns a Vector3 object where each vector component of v has been negated.
Returns a Vector3 that has had each vector component of v multiplied by factor.
Returns a Vector3 that has had each vector component of v multiplied by factor.
Returns a Vector3 where each component of vector v has been divided by divisor. If divisor is 0 then a zero vector is returned instead.
Compares the two vectors and if each of the corresponding components are equal in value then true is returned, false otherwise.
Compares the vectors and returns true if a and b are not equal, false otherwise.
Allows an instance of Vector3 to be written to the ostream and returns a reference to the ostream.
Simply copiesthe components values from the source vector to the detination vector.
